author: Ben Glaze
title: Gordon Brown warns Tory tax credit cuts could split the UK
text:
Gordon Brown has launched a blistering attack on the Tories for slashing tax credits.
The former Prime Minister blasted the “out of touch” Government for slashing support to low-paid workers, with three million families set to lose £1,000 a year .
Working tax credits were brought in by Mr Brown in 2003 when he was Chancellor.
In a hard-hitting speech this evening he warned that axing his flagship policy could hasten the break up of the United Kingdom.
“This week’s Conservative Party Conference has shown the Tories’ true colours on what, in my view, are essential tax credits to support people who are working but still too poor to make ends meet.
“ Jeremy Hunt, the Health Secretary, said that cutting tax credits would teach already hard-working people to work harder, like the Chinese .
“Iain Duncan Smith, the Work and Pensions Secretary, branded tax credits a ‘bribe’ and said that the move would teach parents that ‘children cost money’.
“They are simply out of touch and do not understand that tax credits lift hard working families out of poverty where the breadwinner is on low pay.”
"Out of touch": Jeremy Hunt is target of Gordon Brown's stinging speech
He feared the social security assault due to take effect in April, combined with fears the Tories will backtrack on new welfare powers for Scotland, risked destroying the Union just a year after Scots voted to stay in the UK.
The ex-Labour leader warned there were just two weeks to make two key changes to the Scotland Bill which is back in parliament later this month.
Addressing 300 people at Glasgow University, he called for Scotland to be given “the clear and unambiguous right to top-up welfare benefits” and “an end to any suggestion that a UK government can prevent the Scottish Parliament administering such change if it decides to do so”.
The cross-party Smith Commission into beefing-up devolution recommended giving Holyrood more powers over welfare spending.
Getty Safe hands: Gordon Brown warns of dangers of Tory welfare plans
“Without the changes that give the Parliamentary welfare top-up powers to Scotland, we face a perfect storm - an explosive cocktail of measures that could blow the Union apart - the Conservative Government defying the Smith proposals on welfare, the very issue where their controversial imposition of cuts hits Scotland hard,” added Mr Brown.
“The Government should avoid what would be seen as a double betrayal - breaking their promises to the poor and breaking their promise to deliver the Smith recommendations in full on the very powers that are needed to counteract welfare cuts and the austerity they bring.”
Ex-PM Mr Brown - whose barnstorming speech on the eve of the independence referendum was widely credited with tipping the vote in favour staying in the UK - wrote to David Cameron last month urging the changes.
He argued they were “essential if we are to show the people of Scotland we have honoured our commitment made in the referendum last September”.
He also warned that English Votes for English Laws was an attempt to pit English nationalism against Scottish nationalism in another blow to the Union.
